title: Change OO FQDN
content:
You may need to change the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) of your suite in some scenarios. Here are some examples:
  • Your organization is rebranding its business
  • You need to change the FQDN of the suite before go-live
  • You're pushing a standby environment to production after a disaster recovery
The process described here for changing the FQDN is targetting the change for OMT and suite components only. OO is a component in the suite ecosystem, however because it's deployment lifecycle is decoupled from the rest of the suite, the steps in the page mentioned earlier do not propagate the change to OO. Therefore, the steps described here are to be performed after the FQDN has been changed for OMT and the suite. 

    First, let's establish what needs to be changed for OO, according to how the suite was installed.  

    If the suite is installed on an embedded Kubernetes (for example OMT):

    Changing the FQDN assumes that the suite and OO share the same FQDN, and is a two-step process:

    1. Change FQDN for OMT and the suite
    2. Change FQDN for OO deployment using embedded Kubernetes (see the relevant section below)
    If the suite is installed on a managed Kubernetes (for example EKS):

    There are two FQDNs that can be changed for OO:

    • The OO login URL - this is the public access point of OO, the URL of the public Application Load Balancer that routes traffic to the containerized OO components.
      For example: https://oo.example.com:443
    • The OO integration URL - this is the URL of the internal-facing Application Load Balancer that facilitates the communication between the suite and OO.
      For example: https://internal.oo.example.com:443

    See the architecture details on Install OO Containerized on AWS (EKS) topic.

    Change the FQDN(s) by following the steps in the relevant section below.

      Change FQDN for OO deployment using embedded Kubernetes

      To change FQDN for OO deployed in an embedded Kubernetes environment, perform the following tasks.

      Update values.yaml

      Navigate to your custom values.yaml file that was used with the OO installation, and update the following parameters:

      • global.externalAccessHost
      • (optional) global.externalAccessPort (Only if, besides the host, you also changed the port number of OO)
      • global.ts.cert
      • global.tls.key
      • caCertificates
      Parameter Required Description Default Example
      global.externalAccessHost Yes Update the value with the new FQDN's hostname oo.new.com
      global.externalAccessPort No (Optional) Update the value with the new port number 1234
      global.tls.cert Yes The .pem encoded content of the certificate associated with the new FQDN n/a 
      global:
  tls:
    cert: "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
[...]
Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
[...]
zw==
-----END CERTIFICATE-----"
      global.tls.key Yes The .pem encoded content of the key. n/a 
      global:
  tls:
    key: "-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
[...]
Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
[...]
zw==
-----END CERTIFICATE-----"
      caCertificates Yes

      Provide the same certificate from parameter global.tls.cert.

      This parameter does not exist in values.yaml, you need to manually add it in the file.

      The location of this parameter in the file structure is irrelevant as long as it's defined as first level key index. 

      At this parameter, the certificates that OO is requried to trust (for example: database certificate(s), certificates of various external URLs, etc) are provided - including the certificate associated with the new FQDN. The global.tls.cert|key parameter controls the certificate that OO deployed nginx controller uses. The caCertificates parameter controls the certificates that OO pods need to trust.

      It's important to note that each line of the .pem encoded value must be indented by 4 spaces. Compared to global.tls.cert and global.tls.key parameters, the content of caCertificates parameter must not be enclosed between double quotes. The key index that holds the certificate content can have any name as long as it ends in .crt. For example: caCertificates.oo_new_fqdn_cert.crt. 

      		 n/a 
      acceptEula:
# [...]
caCertificates:
  oo_new_fqdn_cert.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    zw==
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
# [...]
global:

      Update OO deployment

      Run the following command to trigger the update: 

      helm upgrade <OO RELEASE NAME> <OO CHART FILE> --namespace <OO NAMESPACE> -f <VALUES YAML FILE>

      Where,

      • <OO RELEASE NAME> = the release name of the existing OO installation
      • <OO CHART FILE> = the absolute path of the OO chart archive
      • <OO NAMESPACE> = the namespace of OO installation.
      • <VALUES YAML FILE> = the absolute path to your custom values.yaml file that you updated with the new FQDN.

      For example:

      helm upgrade oo oo-1.0.2+202xxx01.xx/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.0.2+202xxx01.xx.tgz --namespace oo -f values.yaml

      Update OO URLs in BO

      After the new FQDN was updated in the OO deployment, change the login and integration URLs in BO for each tenant that has the OO capability enabled. 

      Under Tenants page, click on a tenant ID, then under Capability settings: 

      1. Update the URLs with the new FQDN
      2. Click "Test connection" in order to validate the connection via the new FQDN.
      3. CLick "Save" in order to persiste the change.

      Change FQDN for a deployment using managed Kubernetes

      AWS (EKS)

      In an EKS deployment, the FQDNs you can change are for the following resources:

      1. Public Application Load Balancer for OO
      2. Internal Application Load Balancer for Service Management-OO integration.

      The process for updating the FQDN is the same for both Load Balancers, follow the below steps for the Load Balancer you change the FQDN for:

      1. Ensure that the pre-requisites are met:
        1. You have created the new FQDN in Route 53 AWS service, and you didn't bind it to OO Application Load Balancer.
        2. The certificate for the new FQDN is uploaded in Amazon Certificate Manager (ACM).
      2. Bind the new FQDN with the Application Load Balancer in Route 53
        • Log in to the AWS Management Console with your AWS account.
        • Navigate to All services > Networking & Content Delivery > Route 53 > Hosted Zone.
        • Click your domain and then click your record set.
        • On the Alias tab, click Yes.
        • On the Alias Target tab, type the created OO load balancer's DNS name, for example, dualstack.eks-alb-wj-347689543.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com.
        • On the Evaluate Target Health tab, click Yes.
        • Leave other settings as is, and click Save Record Set.
      3. Update the corresponding ingress resources with the new details (the new certificate ARN, and the new host).
        1. The name of the ingress resource that needs to be updated is:
          Internal ALB: oo-internal-ingress (the name of this resource was defined during step Create an Ingress for integration)
          Public ALB: oo-ingress (the name of this resource was defined during step Create an Ingress for OO)
        2. On the Bastion node, run the following command:
          Internal ALB: kubectl edit ing -n <oo_namespace> oo-internal-ingress
          Public ALB: kubectl edit ing -n <oo_namespace> oo-ingress. Where <oo_namespace> = OO namespace
        3. In the editor, change the following properties:
          Parameter Description
          metadata.annotations.alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn Update the value of this annotation with the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the new certificate you have uploaded to ACM for the new FQDN.
          For example: alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/certificate-arn: arn:aws:acm:eu-central-1:xxxxxxxxxxxx:certificate/b357f377-0179-40f7-90fc-e4af9743bcc4
          spec.tls.hosts Update the value of this property with the new FQDN
          For example: newhost.mydomain.com
          alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports (Optional) If you have also updated the ALB's listening port, then set the port number at this annotation.
          For example: alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports: '[{"HTTPS": 1234}]'
      4. Roll out the changes in OO deployment.

        1. On the Bastion node, navigate to your custom values.yaml file that was used with the OO installation, and update the following parameters: 

          Parameter Required Description Default Example
          global.externalAccessHost Yes Update the value with the new FQDN's hostname of public ALB oo.new.com
          global.externalAccessPort No (Optional) Update the value with the new port number 1234
          caCertificates Yes

          If the certificate(s) used with the below entities are AWS issued, then skip this step.

          Otherwise, provide the certificate(s) according to the FQDN changes:

          • The new FQDN of the suite Load Balancer
          • The new FQDN of the OO public Load Balancer
          • The new FQDN of the OO integration Application Load Balancer

          IMPORTANT:

          • This parameter does not exist in values.yaml, you need to manually add it in the file. The location of this parameter in the file structure is irrelevant as long as it's defined as first level key index. 
          • Each line of the .pem encoded value must be indented by 4 spaces.
          • The key index that holds the certificate content can have any name as long as it ends in .crt
          		 
          acceptEula:
# [...]
caCertificates:
  oo_new_public_cert.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    zw==
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
  oo_new_internal_cert.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    zw==
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
  suite_new_cert.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUKt1lvs8PumbC/EuA9zh9kS8VB88wDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    Fds6sXHELA/5/68GFXTR094SPMvYOo0aRXT6SUU+3P/W
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFPTCCAyWgAwIBAgIULWatOP79cc4535xb1bLaD5RWvikwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    zw==
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
# [...]
global:
        2. On the Bastion node, navigate to OMT installation directory: 
          cd <OMT_External_K8s_2x.x-xxx>/bin
        3. Run the following command: 
          ./helm upgrade <OO RELEASE NAME> <OO CHART FILE> --namespace <OO NAMESPACE> -f <VALUES YAML FILE>
          For example: 
          ./helm upgrade oo oo-1.0.2+202xxx01.xx/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.0.2+202xxx01.xx.tgz --namespace oo -f values.yaml
      5. Import new OO certificates into the suite
        1. Copy the OO certificate(s) to
          • <path-to-global-volume>/certificate/source/
          • <path-to-global-volume>/certificate/cmp/source/
        2. Restart the pods once the certificate is imported
          • Run the following command to get all xruntime-platform pods: 
            kubectl get pods -n <ITSMA_NAMESPACE> | grep xruntime-platform
          • For each pod, run the following command to restart: 
            kubectl delete pod <pod-name> -n <ITSMA_NAMESPACE>
      6. Update OO URLs in BO
        1. ​​​​​​After the new FQDN was updated in the OO deployment, change the login and integration URLs in BO for each tenant that has the OO capability enabled.
        2. Under the Tenants page, click on a tenant ID, then under Capability settings: 
          • Update the URL(s) with the new FQDN(s), according to which one(s) you have changed.
          • Click "Test connection" to validate the connection via the new FQDN.
          • Click "Save" to persist the change.
